head.supplied: 182 Brunswick St ¶ Fitzroy ¶ 3/6/92 ¶ My Dear Sir ¶ ¶ I have a number of species of Tasmanian mosses to examine and name and I find great difficulty therewith by not having my usual reference books b...

div.p: From Richard Bastow to William Henry Archer
RB MSS M15, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.
I have a number of species of Tasmanian mosses to examine and name and I find great difficulty therewith by not having my usual reference books by me, viz,
1. The tracings in water colour of Tasmanian & other mosses are in a square thin manuscript book.
2. The Octavo volume containing register numbers, Mitten's catalogue of Australian mosses & the British catalogue of mosses & Hepaticae.
3. The Tasmanian mosses and Hepaticae, octavo, bound, with register numbers.
4. Stark's small book with marginal notes.
I shall be glad if you can let me have these books back again.

The mosses I am engaged on have been already named by Dr Burchard of Hamburg, he has evidently used Mitten's classification but I think I cannot endorse his new species, if I am not mistaken they are described in some of those above mentioned books, and drawn therein.
I have also a large amount of material collected by myself and by gentlemen in Tasmania that I wish to name, as a nucleus for another collection.

If it would not be too much trouble I should be glad if you could spare me a couple of capsules of each Phasceum, you have plenty of them, I wish to mount them for the microscope and I cannot find any here, my friends in Tasmania do not seem to fall in with them either.
What do you say to going to Box Hill (a sort of gully to the right of station) on Saturday week to look for young Dawsonia and Frullaniae.

p.seg: This is filed as a M letter but this at the end suggests it was to Archer, but why would M have it?? Archer's address is noted by Willis as being in Hawthorn. Two other letters by Bastow to M are specifically adressed to him.
